text: in the months after the BP oil spill
hundreds of sea turtles were recovered
from the orange slicks that stretched
across the Gulf of Mexico for the Kemp's
ridley turtles already a critically
endangered species the spill posed a
devastating blow now a year later the
turtles exposed to oil have mostly
recovered the vast majority of the
turtles that were recovered alive and
those ranged from turtles that were
lightly oiled to moderately oil to very
heavily oiled the vast majority of those
turtles once cleaned and you know given
veterinary care and support survived and
have been released it may take decades
to know the full effect of oil on that
sea turtles but in the meantime there's
another concern for all the live turtles
pulled from the oil there were many more
that washed up dead on gulf shores and
showed no visible signs of oil exposure
so this is a Kemp's ridley it was found
floating northeast of cat island in

looking for clues as to the cause of
death drowning is a concern as is acute
exposure to a toxin dr. Stacy's findings
are part of a massive federal

a
as a part of the normal diet shrimp are

where an animal would be able to gesture

deck bycatch is a major cause of sea

trawls gill nets and hook and line gear
especially gear that does not allow the

prevent turtle deaths federal
regulations require shrimp trawlers to
insert a turtle escape hatch into the
nets or a Ted but enforcement is
difficult in the state of Louisiana has

in contrast Mississippi has strengthened
its protection for turtles most of the

things that we are still looking at in
